speaker: Frasier
text: [_on air_] Well, I think we have time for one last call, who's up next, Roz?

speaker: Roz
text: We have Elliot, on line three.

speaker: Frasier
text: Hello, Elliot.  I'm listening.

speaker: Elliot
text: [_v.o. He sounds like a thirteen year old_] Well, you see Dr. Crane, I have a problem.  I'm a salesman...

speaker: Frasier
text: Ah, a salesman?  How old are you?

speaker: Elliot
text: Forty-three.

speaker: Frasier
text: Forty-three?

speaker: Elliot
text: Yes.

speaker: Frasier
text: Now tell.  Let's be truthful.

speaker: Elliot
text: I'm forty-three.

speaker: Frasier
text: Elliot, we were not born yesterday.  Clearly you are just an adolescent, trying to prove to your little friends how clever you are by getting on the radio.  But you know what you are really doing, you're taking time away from people with real problems.

speaker: Elliot
text: Hey, I'm forty-three, I was born in New Providence, and I have a very young-sounding voice that people make fun of all the time!

speaker: Frasier
text: [_contrite_] Oh, I'm so sorry, Elliot, that was very insensitive of me.

speaker: Elliot
text: Hah!  Gotcha, Dr. Doofus!

speaker: Frasier
text: Yes, indeed you did "get us," Elliot, but we are not so stuffy here on this program that we can't laugh at ourselves from time to time. [_off-air_] Roz, can't you keep these pimply- faced little maggots off the air?! [_on air_] Well, that's our show for today.  This is Dr. Crane signing off and wishing you good mental health.

speaker: Frasier
text: Have a good weekend, Roz.

speaker: Roz
text: Wait, Frasier.  I want to ask you a question, and I want you to give me an honest answer.

speaker: Frasier
text: No, that outfit does not make you look fat.

speaker: Roz
text: Well, that wasn't the question.  But why would you think it was?

speaker: Frasier
text: Well, as a rule, when a woman prefaces a question with "I want an honest answer," that's usually the question.

speaker: Roz
text: Well, I'm not that insecure.

speaker: Frasier
text: Good.  I'm sorry, you were right.  Your question, please.

speaker: Roz
text: Would you say the back of my head is unattractive?

speaker: Frasier
text: Roz, have you completely lost your mind?

speaker: Roz
text: No, I'm serious.  You know how I have season tickets to the Seahawks games?  Well, there's this really cute guy who sits right behind me, and a few weeks ago we said "Hi" and we smiled at each other, but so far he hasn't asked me out yet. So I was thinking there was something, you know, weird about the back of my head.

speaker: Frasier
text: Roz, there could be hundreds of reasons why he hasn't asked you out.

speaker: Roz
text: [_sarcastic_] Thank you, that makes me feel much better.

speaker: Frasier
text: No, no, maybe he's married, maybe he's in a relationship, maybe he's gay.  Or maybe, just maybe, he's there to watch a football game and not cruise for chicks.

speaker: Roz
text: ...Okay, you're right.  I'm being ridiculous.

speaker: Frasier
text: Of course you are.  See you Monday.

speaker: Roz
text: All right. [_sits back down_] _Before he leaves, however, Frasier can't help staring at the back of her head.  She catches him._

speaker: Roz
text: I saw that! [_he runs out of the booth, she chases him to get his opinion_] Wait! **HEIR TO THE THRONE**  _Scene Two - Frasier's apartment. He is sitting at the table whilst Eddie stares at him._

speaker: Frasier
text: You are not getting the rest of my scone, so just forget it... [_takes a bite out of scone_] Mmm.  Really good, too.  Yum, yum yum yum... Listen, I don't care, you can sit there 'til you're blue in the face... As far as I'm concerned, you don't even exist, you're not even here... [_he goes back to reading his paper, but soon crumbles under Eddie's unrelenting stare_] Oh, all right, here! Get fat!  _He gives the rest of the scone to Eddie, who runs off with it. Martin enters._

speaker: Martin
text: Ah, got you again, huh?  You're such a soft touch.

speaker: Frasier
text: I am not.

speaker: Martin
text: Well, he never begs while I'm eating.

speaker: Frasier
text: Maybe he doesn't like what you're eating.

speaker: Martin
text: Trust me, he's not picky.  I saw him eat a beetle.

speaker: Daphne
text: Eddie?!  Let's go for another walk.

speaker: Martin
text: I thought you already walked him this morning?

speaker: Daphne
text: I did, twice.

speaker: Martin
text: He's gotta go again?

speaker: Daphne
text: No, actually I do! [_she catches herself as Martin and Frasier give her sharp looks_] That didn't sound right.  There's a very nice-looking gentleman who plays frisbee in the park with his Labrador.  Eddie and I are hoping to run into them again. Come on, Eddie. [_pulls his leash, Eddie doesn't want to move_] He's just playing hard to get.

speaker: Frasier
text: I'm glad somebody is.

speaker: Martin
text: Hey Frasier, how about fixing that toilet of yours?  It keeps running all the time, the noise is driving me crazy.

speaker: Frasier
text: All right, Dad.  I'll call a plumber.

speaker: Martin
text: What do you mean, "Call a plumber?"  You've got two hands, fix it yourself.

speaker: Frasier
text: Dad, I am a doctor.  I have more important things to do with my life than to fix a toilet.

speaker: Niles
text: Good news, Frasier.  I pulled some strings with the spa, and they're squeezing us in for a salt glow with our Swedish massage.

speaker: Frasier
text: Fabulous!

speaker: Martin
text: Ah, forget about a plumber, I'll do it myself.  My manicurist cancelled on me.

speaker: Frasier
text: Dad, you will not do it yourself.

speaker: Martin
text: I'll bet you don't even have any tools around here.

speaker: Frasier
text: Oh well, that's where you're wrong.  Let me show you something, mister.  Here... _He opens a drawer and pulls out a pocket toolkit.  It's like a Swiss Army knife, but has pliers, allan keys, etc. instead of blades.  Very useful when it's in the glove compartment of your car, but you try using it to remove the battery strap when you're stuck in the middle of nowhere!_

speaker: Frasier
text: See this?  Every possible tool for every possible need. Got this from Hammacher-Schlemmer.

speaker: Niles
text: Is that turquoise inlay?

speaker: Frasier
text: Yes, it also comes in ebony and onyx.

speaker: Niles
text: Onyx.  Onyx is so showy.  I don't...

speaker: Frasier
text: Oh, I don't think so.  I love onyx, onyx is a stone that resonates within me...

speaker: Martin
text: This is why I never took any home movies.  You two realize what a couple of delicate doilies you are?  Sheesh, you don't even know the meaning of the word self-reliant.  Thank God there's not a national disaster happening, you'd be helpless. [_exits_]

speaker: Niles
text: [_examining the toolkit_] Oh!  A lemon zester!

speaker: Frasier
text: Yes... You know Niles, I'd actually like to fix that toilet, just to prove Dad wrong.

speaker: Niles
text: Frasier, when a man is born with superior genes, the last challenge he should face involving a toilet is learning how to use one.

speaker: Frasier
text: Yes, but we-we've conquered the intellectual world, but in the world of nuts and bolts we're at the mercy of tradesmen.

speaker: Niles
text: You're serious?

speaker: Frasier
text: Yes!  We could borrow some tools and fix it ourselves. It would be good practical experience, and it would shut Dad up.

speaker: Niles
text: We'll show him!  We're made of tougher stuff than he thinks!

speaker: Frasier
text: Exactly.

speaker: Niles
text: And it's early.  We can let the Eucalyptus wrap be our reward. **IF YOU WANT IT DONE RIGHT...**  _Scene Three - Frasier's bathroom. As you'd expect, it's the height of good taste.  Frasier is pondering a ball-cock while reading a "How to do it" manual, as Niles phones Maris.  (Of course Frasier has a phone in his bathroom!)_

speaker: Niles
text: [_on phone_] Maris.  I'm afraid I'll be delayed a few hours. Frasier and I have taken it upon ourselves to tackle a home repair.  Yes, I'm working with my hands... Yes, I've worked up a bit of a sweat... I suppose I could take my shirt off.

speaker: Frasier
text: Niles, what are you doing?

speaker: Niles
text: She seems to be getting aroused at my attempt at manual labor. [_on phone_] Maris?  I'm holding some sort of wrench...

speaker: Frasier
text: [_taking phone_] Give me that! [_on phone_] Hello, Maris?  Maris, Niles is busy now... No, never mind what I'm wearing. [_hangs up_] May we continue, please?

speaker: Niles
text: Fine.  All right. [_starts reading out instructions_] "Take the ball-cock assembly, thread it through the tank hole."

speaker: Frasier
text: Done.

speaker: Niles
text: "And fasten it under the tank with a lock-nut."

speaker: Frasier
text: Yes, very well, lock-nut.  You see Niles, until today, you didn't even know what a locknut was.

speaker: Niles
text: That Niles is dead.  Call me Dutch.

speaker: Frasier
text: You know Niles, working with our hands like this, I'm reminded of that glorious tradition of the Amish barn raising.  All the men of the village coming together, the mind, the muscle, all toward that simple, yet extraordinary goal. [_replaces the tank lid_] All right... we are ready to flush.

speaker: Niles
text: Here's to what the Crane brothers can accomplish when they put their minds to it.  Flush away.

speaker: Frasier
text: It's working!  Oh my God, it's working.  Look, it's draining out of the tank, into the bowl...

speaker: Niles
text: It's filling the bowl, and then the tank -- oh, I've seen it a million times, but never has it meant so much!

speaker: Frasier
text: It's glorious.

speaker: Niles
text: Frasier?  Shouldn't it be stopping now?

speaker: Frasier
text: One would think so, yes. _The bowl overflows.  The Crane boys panic.  Frasier retreats while Niles perches on the step of the bathtub._

speaker: Niles
text: Ohh, ohh!

speaker: Frasier
text: Ohh! [_referring to instructions_] Look it up. What does it say to do now?

speaker: Niles
text: [_flipping rapidly_] It says - oh, it says nothing!  Where are all your Amish friends now?! **THE CIRCLE OF LIFE**  _Scene Four - Living Room Niles hands Frasier a glass of wine._

speaker: Niles
text: The plumber's been called, the wine is properly chilled, suddenly my world makes sense again.

speaker: Frasier
text: We've had a tough day.  We've tangled with a little pipe and porcelain.  Now it's Montrachet time.

speaker: Niles
text: When you think about it, our only mistake today was trying to fix that toilet ourselves.

speaker: Frasier
text: Yes, we tampered with the natural order of things.

speaker: Niles
text: But now, order has been restored.  By hiring a plumber, that plumber can now afford, say, a Dolly Parton album.  Miss Parton can then finance a national tour which will, of course, come to Seattle, allowing some local promoter to make enough money to send his cross-dressing teenaged son to us for $150- an-hour therapy.

speaker: Frasier
text: [_raises his glass_] To the circle of life.

speaker: Frasier
text: That must be the plumber.

speaker: Martin
text: Well, are you going to answer that, or are you going to hire somebody to do that for you too?

speaker: Frasier
text: Dad, we tried, okay? _The doorbell bing-bongs again.  Daphne enters from the hallway carrying a mop and wearing long yellow rubber gloves.  She's obviously been cleaning up the mess in the toilet._

speaker: Daphne
text: Oh please, I wasn't doing anything.  Let me get it.

speaker: Danny
text: Somebody call for a plumber?

speaker: Daphne
text: Not nearly soon enough.

speaker: Martin
text: Follow me. [_he and Danny exit to toilet_]

speaker: Daphne
text: What a lovely way to spend an afternoon.

speaker: Frasier
text: Well Daphne, we're not plumbers, we're psychiatrists.

speaker: Daphne
text: Yeah, well there are some heads you shouldn't tamper with.

speaker: Niles
text: Frasier, you've got to get him out of here.

speaker: Frasier
text: What?

speaker: Niles
text: That man is not fit to touch your toilet!

speaker: Frasier
text: Niles, have you been self-medicating again?

speaker: Niles
text: That was Danny Kreizel.

speaker: Frasier
text: "Kreizel the Weasel?"  How can you be sure, it's been twenty- five years.

speaker: Niles
text: I'd recognize him anywhere.  He bullied me throughout my entire childhood!

speaker: Frasier
text: He certainly didn't recognize you just now.

speaker: Niles
text: Well, perhaps that was because he wasn't sticking my head down a toilet and FLUSHING IT!  That was his trademark.  He called it... a swirly.

speaker: Frasier
text: Niles, you don't have to remind me of the Kreizel reign of terror.  I'm quite convinced I can trace my fear of confined spaces back to the time when his older brother Billy shoved me into a locker, wearing a girl's field hockey uniform!

speaker: Niles
text: I'm sorry, I didn't mean to deny you your pain.

speaker: Frasier
text: Thank you.

speaker: Niles
text: [_back to his own pain_] I can still hear the laughter, and Kreizel's mocking voice as he'd hoist me over the bowl. "Hold your breath, Jocko!"  Then the crowd would start its awful chant.  "There goes Crane, Down the Drain!" [_starts to bow over the armchair_] "There goes Crane, Down the..."

speaker: Frasier
text: NILES!  Niles, get a hold of yourself!  Stop it!  Stop, stop. It's all right.  You're no longer an awkward teenager, you're a renowned psychiatrist.  Danny Kreizel may have won a battle or two back in junior high, but that's where he peaked.  You won the war.  You know the expression, "Living well is the best revenge"?

speaker: Niles
text: It's a wonderful expression.  Just don't know how true it is. Don't see it turning up in a lot of opera plots.  "Ludwig, maddened by the poisoning of his entire family, wreaks vengeance on Gunther in the third act by living well."

speaker: Frasier
text: All right, Niles. [_heads into the kitchen_]

speaker: Niles
text: [_follows him_] "Whereupon Woton, upon discovering his deception, wreaks vengeance on Gunther in the third act again by living even better than the Duke."

speaker: Frasier
text: Oh, all right! _CUT TO: Frasier's bathroom. Danny is fixing the toilet, Martin is keeping an eye on his work._

speaker: Martin
text: That's a _new_ part, right?

speaker: Danny
text: Yeah.

speaker: Martin
text: 'Cause I'm sure you're charging me for a new part, so I wouldn't want you charging me for a used part.

speaker: Danny
text: What are you, the plumbing police?

speaker: Martin
text: [_exiting_] I'll be back.

speaker: Niles
text: Don't mind me, just came in for some aspirin.  Tannic acid gives me the tiniest headache.  That's the price I pay for drinking nothing but expensive wine.

speaker: Danny
text: [_not reacting to jibe_] Hey. [_whistles to get Niles's attention_] You got a real mess here.  I'm gonna have to call the shop, have my partner bring out a whole lotta new parts. You're looking at two guys on golden time, is that okay with you?

speaker: Niles
text: It's only money.  Hmph...

speaker: Danny
text: Say, uh, has somebody been trying to fix this thing?

speaker: Niles
text: Not me.  I don't even set the clock in my _Mercedes E320_.

speaker: Danny
text: Boy, that's a nice car.

speaker: Niles
text: Yes, I should say it is.

speaker: Danny
text: Yeah, I had one for a while.  But it was too small for the whole family, so we upgraded to the S class.

speaker: Niles
text: You have the big Mercedes?

speaker: Danny
text: Oh, yeah.  And I gotta tell you, my 13 year-old's already got his eye on it.  That's a great kid right there.  Except he got in a fight at school the other day.

speaker: Niles
text: Oh, really? [_reaches out to flush the toilet_] With some small- boned child with superior language skills? _Danny looks up, causing Niles to pull his hand away and act as though he were stretching._

speaker: Danny
text: Nah.  It was some big jerk on the football team who tried to steal his lunch money.

speaker: Niles
text: Ah.

speaker: Danny
text: Yeah. [_bows his head in again_]

speaker: Niles
text: Well, there's nothing like a bully. _He raises his foot to push Danny's head in, but Danny looks up again, causing Niles to grab his foot and flex his leg behind his back, again as if stretching._

speaker: Danny
text: Well, I gotta tell you, I'd rather he'd be a bully than one of those wussy kids that always get picked on.  You know the kind I'm talking about?  Kids who are too gutless to fight back?

speaker: Niles
text: You admire someone who fights back, do you?

speaker: Danny
text: Well, sure. I mean, if you don't fight back, what are you? You're a wuss, you're a wimp, you're a...  _Frasier enters in time to stop Niles lunging at Danny. Danny doesn't notice._

speaker: Frasier
text: STOP!  Niles, leave the man alone while he's trying to work!  _END OF ACT ONE  ACT TWO  Scene Five - Living Room Niles angrily paces back and forth on the balcony.  Each time he passes by Frasier's ficus tree, he swats it with his hand.  Frasier stands inside, watching him. Daphne enters._

speaker: Daphne
text: What's Dr. Crane doing?

speaker: Frasier
text: He's a little frustrated because I wouldn't let him do something.  He's taking his anger out on my ficus.

speaker: Daphne
text: I've never seen him so angry, he's like a madman. _Niles's arm waving gets more extreme, until he's wildly flinging his arms about.  Sensing something wrong, Frasier lets him in._

speaker: Niles
text: Good Lord!  There's a bee out there the size of a wood finch!

speaker: Frasier
text: Niles, you've had a chance to cool off.  Are you ready to talk about this now?

speaker: Niles
text: No, I'm not ready yet. _He goes into the kitchen.  Frasier follows.  Daphne looks through the telescope, searching the park for the man with the Labrador.  Reset to: Kitchen._

speaker: Frasier
text: Niles, I have to be honest.  I'm a little disappointed in you. Were you actually going to stick another human being's head into a toilet?

speaker: Niles
text: [_getting soda from fridge_] You don't seem to understand, I feel this RAGE!  It's as if this BEAST has been awakened within me! [_he can't get the top off the bottle_] Could you get that for me?

speaker: Frasier
text: Niles, you see, there is a beast in all of us.  Part of becoming a rational adult is learning to control it. That's what separates us from the Kreizels of this world.

speaker: Niles
text: That and their tendency to squat on their haunches and groom each other.

speaker: Frasier
text: Don't you see?  You have an opportunity with Danny that I never had with Billy.  To confront him as a rational adult and achieve some closure.

speaker: Niles
text: Easier said than done, Frasier.  One look at that oafish face, those dead Kreizel eyes, and you see there is no chance for communication.

speaker: Frasier
text: Yes, there is, Niles.  There has to be.

speaker: Niles
text: I can't go in there and talk to him.  If the coward turns his back on me, I'll attack him again.

speaker: Frasier
text: No, you won't.  You're not a child anymore. [_taking Niles by the hand_] Now come with me, I'm taking you to the bathroom!  _Reset to: Bathroom Danny and his partner are still working on the toilet as Frasier and Niles enter._

speaker: Niles
text: Excuse me sir, I'd like to have a word with you.

speaker: Danny
text: Yeah, go ahead.

speaker: Niles
text: I'd like to take you back in time to the 1970's.  There was an intellectually gifted young student at John Adams Junior High. You took it upon yourself to terrorize that student, simply because he was different from you. I was that student.

speaker: Danny
text: No kidding?

speaker: Niles
text: I was hoping we could step into the living room and come to some sort of understanding.

speaker: Danny
text: It's okay with me.  Any room in the house is still fifty-nine bucks an hour. [_drops a tool into his toolbox_] I'll be right back, Billy.

speaker: Frasier
text: _Billy_? _From beneath the toilet rises Danny's older, more heavyset brother Billy._

speaker: Billy
text: Ah, that's my brother for ya.  Always getting into stuff. But if you ask me, your friend over there is getting all worked up over nothing.

speaker: Frasier
text: You think so, Billy?

speaker: Billy
text: Kids pick on other kids, it's part of growing up. If anything, it made those weak kids tougher.

speaker: Frasier
text: Really?

speaker: Billy
text: Come on, you're a big guy.  You must have been involved in some kinda stuff?

speaker: Frasier
text: Oh, I was involved...  _For a moment Frasier wants to give in to his beast.  Then he looks back toward the hallway, remembering his advice to Niles._

speaker: Frasier
text: Billy, I would like to take you back in time...

speaker: Billy
text: [_stands_] No.  Let me take YOU back.  I remember once, we jammed this poindexter into a locker, wearing a girl's field hockey uniform! [_laughs_] _CUT TO: Living Room Niles is standing sideways, presenting his profile to Danny._

speaker: Danny
text: No, I'm sorry.  I just don't remember you.

speaker: Niles
text: Well, perhaps you'll remember third period gym class. You used to make me wear my jockstrap like a tiara?

speaker: Danny
text: Oh, yeah!  Were you the kid who used to carry his gym shorts in an attache case?

speaker: Niles
text: ...It was a valise.

speaker: Danny
text: I remember you.  Boy, those were some crazy times.  You ever see any of the old gang?

speaker: Niles
text: Look, you're missing the point.  I was severely scarred by those experiences...

speaker: Danny
text: Hey, wait a minute.  I can't defend everything I did back in junior high, I mean who can?  But let's face it, when you show up at school wearing a tweed blazer with elbow patches and carrying a valise, I mean, I think the guilt here is fifty- fifty.  _CUT TO: Bathroom Billy is still enjoying the trip down memory lane._

speaker: Billy
text: He's yelling at us something about "repressed tendencies," so we stuffed a fire extinguisher down his pants!  We called it... [_thinks_]

speaker: Frasier
text: [_slapping a tube of toothpaste into his palm_] A _jet pack._

speaker: Billy
text: [__howling with laughter__] That's it!  Man, you remember them all.  _CUT TO: Living Room Now Danny is seated on the couch while Niles is sitting on the edge of Martin's Chair._

speaker: Niles
text: Well then, my next question to you would be "Why would you behave this way?"

speaker: Danny
text: Well, I don't know.  I mean, I guess because people thought it was funny.

speaker: Niles
text: I see, I see.  So then, to get this validation, you would, say, squeeze my head between your ankles and hop around the lunch room?

speaker: Danny
text: I did that to you?

speaker: Niles
text: Yes.  How does that make you feel?

speaker: Danny
text: ...Well, kinda bad!

speaker: Niles
text: The healing has begun!

speaker: Billy
text: So, so in front of the whole bus, we pants him!  He's yelling at us, [_squeaky voice_] "Gimme back my pants!"  But - whoops! -- they fell out the window!  _CUT TO: Living Room. By this time, Danny is lying on the couch._

speaker: Niles
text: So then it's possible these acts of aggression were misplaced outbursts aimed at your father.

speaker: Danny
text: [_almost in tears_] Yes.

speaker: Niles
text: He was the real bully, wasn't he?

speaker: Danny
text: Oh, yes!

speaker: Niles
text: Let it out, Danny, let it out!

speaker: Danny
text: Nothing I ever did was good enough for him! [_sits up_] I am so sorry that I picked on you, man.  I just wanted to be good at something, and I was good at that.

speaker: Niles
text: [_puts his hand on Danny's shoulder_] You were the best.

speaker: Billy
text: Then we made him hula in his underwear in front of all the girls! [_laughs and dips his head back in the toilet_] You shoulda been there!

speaker: Frasier
text: I WAS there! [_lunges at Billy_]

speaker: Danny
text: Thanks. This has just been terrific for me.

speaker: Niles
text: I can't take all the credit.  Half the thanks belongs to my brother.  He convinced me a civilized person can work anything out, as long as he approach it in a calm, rational manner.

speaker: Frasier
text: Run, Niles, run!  The beast is loose!  _Billy charges in, dripping wet and fit to kill.  He chases Frasier out the front door.  FADE TO:  Scene Six - Frasier's bathroom. Frasier and Eddie watch as Martin fixes the toilet._

speaker: Martin
text: So you really shoved his head right in here?

speaker: Frasier
text: I don't know, Dad.  It's all really sort of a blur.  I guess I just lost control.

speaker: Martin
text: Bet it felt good though, didn't it?

speaker: Frasier
text: No... it felt _damn_ good.

speaker: Martin
text: [_laughs_] Ah, it's too bad you didn't do it twenty years ago, you could have given him a much better swirly.  These low-flow toilets don't have the same velocity as the old ones.  So what did he do to you?

speaker: Frasier
text: He didn't have the nerve to do a thing.

speaker: Martin
text: You paid him off, huh?

speaker: Frasier
text: I've never written a check so quickly in my life.

speaker: Martin
text: [_flushing toilet_] Well, there she goes.  Good as new.

speaker: Frasier
text: Thanks, Dad.  Can I buy you a beer?

speaker: Martin
text: Oh yeah, sounds good. [_gets up_] Come on, Eddie. _They start to leave.  Eddie runs to the toilet and drinks from the bowl._

speaker: Martin
text: Oh, for God's sake Eddie, don't drink out of the toilet. Some guy just had his head in there!
